I bet a million dollars the ones that are cut long way, with the grain, would make a much more smooth, clear, & stronger result that the crosscut pieces. ‘Reason being is this:
When looking through the finished product of the cross cut (the ones that take up the resin so much easier) is that you are essentially looking down the grain at a bunch of densely packed tiny circles. This pattern of tiny circles is why they never come out smooth and why the cracking looks the way it does and is unpredictable....Capillary action via many various sources of internal pressure pulling inward thereby pulling the whole thing into multiple pieces.
When looking“sideways” through the grain of the pieces cut with the grain you are looking through the thinnest part of each individual grain; a series of hollow cylinders stacked on top of each other, rather than than trying to look through a densely packed pattern via the densest perspective of its cross-section. I promise It would result in a much smoother finish than the cross cut sections as it wouldn’t present the sand-like grain pattern created by a bunch of tightly packed circles, but the “sides” of a mere fraction of the number of grains, which actually have strength of uniformity not provided by the easily crumbled cross-cut pieces, aligned in a way that they present longest and smoothest part of themselves .
I know it’s much harder to penetrate the center of those pieces as the distance is so much further, but I see the benefits in cracking that code will be exponential

So THAT'S why firewood looks weird in its charcoal state. It'll be individual square shaped peices which aren't at all constant with their shape or still have its a portion of its log structure depending on how long it was on fire (or how long the wood was burning) and in both instances the log(s) may have embers on them and the small chunks of coal would still be orange hot and all the cool and non burning coal will have an ashy appearance, but I found that quenching the fire with water will both cool everything that's either still smoldering or on fire and wash away the ash and reveal the black coal which I found interesting considering that I'm partially a pyromaniac

With a length-wise piece, have you thought about suspending it over the resin, and using the cellulose tubes as a straw to suck up the resin?
And using a form of a glass press while the epoxy cures.

Also, you could use a UV reactive resin and leave it in a press and calculate the UV exposure to equate to a 72 hr cure time.
The slower the cure time the more durable the resin will be because it can bend like steel, the faster the more brittle it is again like steel.
This is my experience working with epoxy resins in the marble and granite industry.
But again the UV exposure could reach the interior of the wood because of its transparency.

Additionally, you could try vacuum forming it in a bag against a piece or between two pieces of glass (as a forming mold) like they do with fiberglass, carbon fiber, kevlar, etc.

Make sure to measure the space of the bag to be enough to suck it into and then through the wood, and then move any excess away from it to make it easy to trim the excess flash resin away.

If you ever try this again, use a mold, put a small pane of glass on the bottom, spray with resin mold release, pull your vacuum cycles, then lay another release-sprayed piece of glass on top (no pressure, just lay it there). Let cure fully -- this should prevent the warping, and ensure the resin forms to the piece's thickness properly, ensuring you'll have a nice flat piece.

If the pieces get TOO thin (ie: the top glass's own weight creates too much pressure), mix a microbatch of the resin, use a glass stir rod to make tiny drops on a piece of resin mold release sprayed glass. After these fully cure, do as above, but, place one at each corner of the bottom glass as spacers to keep the top glass from sinking too far.

I know it's like 3 years later but I think the issue here is that you didn't use a thin enough resin. There's this stuff I keep seeing in resin casting videos that is... Uhhh... I think it's called "Stabilizer", or its got another name and the process that is involved is called "stabilizing". Either way, it's a very thin resin, and it's used to fill in and stabilize (or "solidify" if that word actually has any meaning in this context) any potentially absorbent points on the wood before working with a thicker resin. This allows the wood to be more easily turned after all the required resin is used. My guess is it would take a looooong time to cure, though.
But I'm just a guy who watches woodturning videos, to note. I don't actually know the properties of said resins, so you'll probably want to consult an actual wood turner to correct what I mistakes I might have made and to get more detail on the properties of the resin.

Very interesting to see your process of trying to reverse engineer this transparent wood. It's a shame that the authors of the paper left out so much key detail. One of the most important aspects of sharing research is to make it so that others can reproduce and verify your findings. Releasing a paper that fails to fully explain the details of the method to reproduce it ruins that and leads to a distrust of science. It's entirely possible that such beautiful transparent wood is possible to make, but without knowing how, it may as well have been faked. Still, it seems you intuition and expertise lead you in the right direction and the end product demonstrates that it's at least possible.

A couple of thoughts:
(1.) Oxalic acid is used to whiten wood in industrial processes and as a pretreatment before using colored dyes or stains. I think it's also what's used to "bleach" sugar and flour.
(2.) This process isn't too dissimilar from making stabilized wood used for making things like duck calls, pool cues and knife scales. Some of the trade names are Frostwood and Dymondwood. You can buy an epoxy designed to be soaked up by the wood for stabilizing called "cactus juice". Pigments are usually added to it but it comes clear.
(3.) Wood always warps like that when it dries. It's called "cupping". You need to figure a way to clamp it while it's under vacuum pressure.
I think if you look into how people stabilize birch plywood for making knife scales and the like that you may be able to borrow some ideas and techniques from it.

If ever you wish to exhaustively remove lignin this extraction should be done as many times as required until the solution is colorless. You can test to see if there is any remaining in the wood by taking a thin slice and treating it with a drop or two of phloroglucinol which stains lignin bright red.. I doubt you really need to go to such lengths but some woods do contain quite a lot of lignin in secondary thickened areas. The lignin thickening is a major source of the tensile properties of wood so of course as a composite it might lose some of that. Some difficult to work burl woods are treated with resin impregnation to render them stronger and more easily worked on a lathe.

If you just want transparent wood rather than a composite (which is obviously much stronger) its just a matter of gradually removing the sodium salts in water then removing water gradually through first increasing concentrations of say Isopropanol in water and then from pure isopropanol through increasing concentrations of xylene in isopropanol.or use any other solvent with a refractive index as close to that of air as possible. That way you can obtain something with the minimum translucency and maximum transparency. It will never be completely transparent because of light scattering by the cellulose fibers.

A similar technique is used in microscopy

I realize this video is almost a year old by now, and there might be another comment around mentioning the same I will now, but I didn't see any when taking a quick look so here it goes:

As someone who works regularly with resin for art and crafting projects, I can tell you that resin shrinks slightly when it cures. How much it shrinks depends on the type and brand of resin, and slow-curing resin tends to shrink a bit less, but it always shrinks.
So, when there isn't a firm surface for the resin to rest on during that process, it'll bend and/or crack.
If you don't want bent resin, wait for your pieces to be fully cured before peeling them off.

Polishing the top and bottom surface should drastically improve the transparency of the final product.

Placing a flat sheet of glass on top of the pieces and letting them fully cure over 36-48 hours before pealing them off might help prevent the cupping.

To avoid the violent splashing when pulling the vacuum, you need to crack open the vacuum release valve to control the rate of pressure change in the chamber.
This lets you remove the air in the Resin without letting it boil over the edge of the mould.
Once it stops bubbling, you can then close the valve and pull down to the full vacuum. From what I've seen in other videos, once the chamber has been pulled down as far as it can be, let it sit at that vacuum for a minute or 2 and then, turn off the pump and slowly release the vacuum and let the piece set up as normal, keeping it under vacuum can cause some odd effects to occur.

If you ever work with Epoxy Resin again...

1) Measure both parts in the same graduated cup, don't use separate cups as that can cause problems during Curing, there are several out there that are marked for different Epoxy Ratios (fill to 1st line with part A, then fill to 2nd line with part B). Mix with with something shaped like a paint stir stick (flat sides and tip) and scrape both the sides and bottom frequently while stirring, this makes sure you mix ALL of the Resin together and don't end up with problems because some of the mix didn't have the proper proportions of A & B. You can also use a paint paddle stirrer in a drill gun but you should vacuum the air out of the mix afterwards or the final product will have LOTS of bubbles in it.

2) Whatever container you use as a mould or drying rack should be either lined with builders tape (ask at Home Depot or Lowes for the tape used to seal the seams of building wrap during home construction) OR sprayed with Mould Release OR coated with a thin application of paste wax (used by wood workers, this will make it MUCH easier to get the Resin off/out of the mould without stress or damage; see Modustrial Maker (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9aRTgvFLqnK1S0RsWZzlMw/videos?view=0&sort=dd&flow=grid) for examples - what he uses when he makes a concrete countertop will work just fine.

3) If you need the Epoxy Resin to REALLY penetrate your work piece, mix the Resin according to the Manufactures directions, then add an equal volume of acetone to thin it out. Kim Tippen (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChOkCqsbNr6K1RYi9Sadb5Q/videos?view=0&sort=dd&flow=grid) uses this trick when shes trying to stiffen up a piece of very soft/rotten wood that she's turning on her Lathe.

In addition to Kim Tippen,
Doug at Pohl Barn (https://www.youtube.com/user/treerat6419/videos?sort=dd&view=0&flow=grid)
Peter Brown (https://www.youtube.com/user/kludge1977/videos?flow=grid&view=0&sort=dd)
and
Nick Zametti (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC3-0S7vXfwYY2jj5EkMpymA/videos)
also do a LOT of wood & Resin projects if you want some ideas/tips.

A Great Video!

May I share some WOODWORKING ADVICE?

To cut such thin pieces, SAFELY, First Lower your blade BELOW THE TABLE!

Now, lay down some GOOD 2 inch masking tape, with the "middle" being where the blade will eventually be brought back up (while the SAW is turned ON!) You might even layer two masking tapes for a more sturdy surface.

Turning on the SAW and raising it, you will naturally cut EXACTLY the "Kerf" of your blade (Kerf: df. the Width of the cut, REGARDLESS of what style teeth your saw has.

NEXT.

Return to using your fence, WITH AN ADDITIONAL BOARD, clamped (or better double sided tape it to the fence. This Board PROVIDES a free falling away from the blade, so your wood will not have "Burn Marks" on it. The End of the Board on your fence, should be where the saw blade begins the cut.

Finally, Always use a "PUSH Stick" Say a 2X4 about 20 inches long, and push your BASS WOOD through the saw blade As Well as the Push Stick. KEEP YOUR FINGERS SAFE!

Now, about me, a bit: I have worked both Hard Wood & Soft woods for Sixty Years.

After I retired I started doing things like MAKING wood Book Markers, about .035 to .040 Inches thick. I really know how to cut such thin pieces, and I used some very exotic woods.

the First thing I did AFTER CUTTING THEM, was almost flood them with thin viscosity Super glue, to get into those fibers! I would then use double sided tape and stick them to extruded Aluminum that was very flat, and start my sanding.

I would reapply that super glue, as needed, and sand to 1200 Grit!. I soaked off the double sided tape with Alcohol, applied it to the SANDED SIDE and sand the other side until 1200 grit!

These book marks were TRANSLUCENT, and held to a good white light, you would see everything your Chemical baths removed, Some Birds Eye Maple pieces looked like Butterfly Wings !!!

Keep on doing your experiments, MINE started in 1957, building my first Radio! And I have worked in Electronics, Wood, And Metallurgical Arts ALL MY LIFE!

Hence my nick name Mad Sigh N Tist !

really cool idea. would it be possible to use your vacuum more efficiently to both draw out the chemicals you used to pre pare the wood and to draw in the epoxy. One idea would be to use a piece of dowel wood say 100mm long by 25mm diameter. perform the same cleaning and preparation to the piece but focus on the one end. this will more then likely only work on a small length of the piece but that's ok. then to remove the various chemicals, clamp the end that was treated into a pipe fitting of the same diameter (.Probably best to size this first and get the wooden dowel to match.) use your vacuum to pull the chemicals out. once that is complete. trim the wood down to 20mm long or how ever far you think the chemicals penetrated. and fit to vacuum once more. then once your sure the last remaining agents are removed. put the end of the wood not exposed to the vacuum into a container of epoxy resin freshly mixed. allow the vacuum to pull the epoxy through the wood and out the other side. this will remove any air also trapped. turn off the vacuum while it is still immersed in the resin and allow it to stabilise its internal pressures buy continuing to soak up more resin. allow to cure. once its cured it should be possible to cut slivers of the now trans parent wood. some sanding and buffing may be required for the cut surfaces to bring back the transparency.

You can also try making Densified Wood. It starts out with the same de-lignated chips you used for Transparent Wood, but then you clamp them at steam temperatures for about a day between two metal plates. When you release the plates a slip of wood 22% as thick as the original falls out that's several times stronger than natural wood.

The cool thing is that this process also welds wood chips into bigger pieces without adhesives, and can be used to form complex shapes like bowls and boxes. The finished wood is so hard you can drill and tap it like aluminum.

Since flatness and smoothness are clear factors in having it produce great results, i wonder if it could've been possible to create a kind of brace. My thought process is to have 2 rectangular bobby pins on opposite sides of the wood, even better if you can get stainless steel or just steel ones. Sure a small piece of metal would be in the final product, looking kind of like frame to the wood, but it may be able to be removed after the curing, and the added bobby pins would weigh the wood down so it wouldn't float, but also keep it slightly raised enough so the wood would always be surrounded by resin, creating a smooth finish,  while also staying completely straight. I know that may go against the pure transparent wood look, by having a little bit of metal support, but that may end up helping to get much better results, so it would drastically reduce the chance of the wood spontaneously bending. I think this could work fairly well with balsam fir, yellow buckeye, or eastern cottonwood. Mainly you want uniseriate rays, no tyloses, low specific gravity, no spiral thickening. Diffuse pores are great, if they are solitary or come in small groups, and if they don't have much/any marginal parenchyma. Basswood is an okay choice, but not the best choice for this experiment you are doing.

The thing about wood anatomy is that it really does matter what species you use for something like what you are doing here. You are trying to get the best result, so you are going to want the wood that will give the best chance of it working.

Okay so I'm an art student and we break down plant fibers to make paper almost the same way you treat the wood to get the color + stuff in between the fibers out (I know there's a word for that but as I said- art student), using lye to boil/cook the fibers for 3 hours in our case, and then bleaching it with sometimes bleach, sometimes some other chemicals depending on the plant, sometimes we even dye it or leave it as is! Also fun fact: those little fibers you had floating around with the rest of the bleached wood in the first batch were the perfect size to be able to make paper with! And with the resin, maybe filing it down to fit the size of the wood pieces (so it wouldn't be so thick on either side) and sanding it with super fine grain would help with the visibility (if you hadn't already figured out you could just put more resin on the pieces you put directly onto the glass). Anyway its cute to see how a stem field video subject has so much in common with art! If getting resin deep into those length-wise pieces is your issue, try stablizing resin. You leave any ( any ) object in a container full of the stuff and then you leave it in vacuum for a *while*. then when all the air is gone, you're supposed to leave it in the resin for double the mount of time it took you to run the vacuum. When that's finished, you cure the resin by cooking it in an oven or something at a specific temp (can't rememebr what it was off the top of my head but i know it won;t cook the item). So, If you ever take it up again, here is a possibility to do it better. Mainly? Change the resin. The resin you used was most likely a resin meant to seal and or be used to make glass fibre compound material. Its likely not meant to be poured in larger amounts. Thats most likely why it warped and cracked.

What you should use is a one part heat cured resin that can be poured a bit thicker. Those are often used for stabilisation of soft material in concert with a vacuum. They have a low viscosity for that exact purpose. You are also not beholden to any time limits as it only cures if heated over a certain temperature. So you can do a lot of repeat vacuum treatments on one piece over hours. (which is often needed to get the resin deep enough into the material)

I think the best solution here is to skip the epoxy and use the cactus juice they use for stabilizing wood. then you can vacuum draw the fluid into the wood indefinitely. As an alternative, degas the resin parts a and b separately along with the wood all separate to remove atmospheric gas dissolved in the fluid at atmospheric pressure. The wood will just fill back up but perhaps not as densely. Then, mix your resin in a vacuum chamber and add the wood. no air = no bubbles so there is much less to vacuum off. Then as a final step, cure the resin in a pressure pot.  Though i think cactus juice is the best answer.

Hello ! Your video is really nice !
I think I have an idea of why the wood isn't transparent at the end... Understand that I'm an engineer in mechanics, so, I'm not really in my domain here :-p
What I think is that when you cut your wood, you should polish it to have a very nice finish.
In fact, when cutting, I'm pretty sure you crush the micro tubes making the structure of the wood. By doing so, you prevent the epoxy to get inside the wood.
I would recommend to cut your wood at 4 - 5 mm thickness, then polishing it perfectly.
To do so, glue your sand paper on a flat surface, and work the wood on it at hand.
Start with sand paper with a grain of 100, and ALWAYS polish it in the same direction (right to left for instance).
Then, with sandpaper with a grain of 200, polish it, but with a 90° angle until the marks of the first polishing disappear (turn it or go "up-down").
Turn it back of 90°, then polish it, always the same direction, with sand paper of grain 400 until the previous marks disappear
Repeat, turn 90°, then sand paper 800
Again with 1000 or so then 2000.
In the end, you can start to polish by doing circles with a piece of fabric and tooth paste (it's a very small polishing paste in fact ;) )
This is the method used to renew old transparent plastic sheets, like cars lights cases and have it perfectly transparent. (that's where I learned it, btw ;-) )
I'm pretty sure that doing so on both sides of the wood right after cutting could help a lot the epoxy to get in and the light to get through as all the micro tubes will be cut perfectly.
Due to gravity, try to always have the micro tubes vertical, maybe?
Also, maybe try to have it stucked in the middle (not the bottom) of a thick layer of epoxy to avoid it to bend (pure speculation)
If one day the idea of trying that again crosses your mind, I'd gladly watch your video ;)
Have a nice day !

It’s very thin and will only cure when you add heat, meaning you can let it be vacuumed for hours and hours or however long it takes to fully absorb the resin, before curing it with heat when it’s ready. For high viscous resins its actually better to put them under pressure, not vacuum because of the bubbling issue. sounds counter intuitive but works. Push the air out instead of pulling it out. Check out many makers such as Nick Zameti or Peter Brown here on youtube to see those results (resin under pressure comes out like completely clear glass).

If you want to use a vacuum, you need something really low viscosity that will not chemically cure.

Woodworkers will tend to use a stabilizing resin, like "cactus juice", that gets put under vac to pull all the air out and then left overnight for things to settle before repressurizing, then cured in an oven. Sure the refractive index might not match... But if you cant get full penetration then it will not be completely clear anyway. Peter Brown here on YouTube uses this stuff too.

You have a mechanical problem, not a chemical one.
Epoxy is trying to displace air in the material, which is difficult for something so viscous to permeate small channels.
You can either try vacuum filling the epoxy to remove the air the material, this is vacuum bag curing composites.
If you still have problems, that's when you can use an air-over system inject epoxy into your evacuated bag, although that's a more difficult setup.

There is a resin pre-soak solution for porous objects. You place the item in solution, then use a vacuum chamber for 24 hrs. The solution replaces all the air. When you apply the resin of choice and vacuum chamber it, there is very little bubbling and when it hardens the resin soaks in better.

1. Replace water gradually by put the treated wood in enough volume of methanol (3 times by 6 hours), acetone (3 times by 6 hours), finally in xylene (2 times by two days).
2. Dissolving epoxy resin in xylene to form solution (e.g. slow curing epoxy 1 : xylene 10), put the xylene treated wood in such dilute epoxy solution under vacuum.
3. Take out the impregnated wood and cure it in vacuum oven (e.g. 85~100 C)
4. Repeat 2 and 3 for several times until wood becomes transparent.

Hint: read the "Paraffin Processing of Tissue" and "epoxy embedding protocol" such as the links below

To dry the wood without the micro tube structure shrinking, soak it in lab grade ethanol to remove all water, then put the piece in a pressure chamber at an extremely high pressure, then heat the ethanol to its boiling point. Vent the container carefully, and you will have an intact piece of dried wood.

Could balsa wood perhaps be more porous and perhaps be a better choice than basswood? Also after treating the wood would heating it slowly in an oven for while perhaps remove water and open the pores a bit? Then perhaps degas it a bit in the vacuum chamber before applying the epoxy. Also could a process of alternating repeatedly between high vacuum and high pressure perhaps be helpful? My thinking is that hitting it with higher pressure shortly after degassing it with vacuum might help push the epoxy into the wood. Would methanol be slightly better than ethanol? Would agitation, perhaps by having the entire vacuum chamber/pressure pot sitting on top of some kind of vibrating platform possibly help? Also I think looking for the lowest viscosity and longest pot life epoxy might be worthwhile, through it seemed the one you were using may have already have such properties. Perhaps talking to an epoxy manufacturer could get some tips on finding an optimum formula resin. Also, I think there might a temperature sweet spot for soaking the wood in the resin. Higher temps will obviously lower the viscosity. and might open the pores of the wood a bit due to expansion. However, higher temps will also shorten the pot life and speed the setup up of the resin. As such there might be some sweet spot temp to balance those factors against each other. Anyway, I look forward to seeing you explore this further someday.

Not always possible, but Youtubers should hew as close to this standard as they can. Overall excellent and fascinating video that transmits both knowledge and technique. I once used alternating positive and negative pressure to impregnate plywood with a resin. The plywood was porous and finely laminated enough that permeation was good even without denaturing the wood beforehand. I wasn't after transparency, but strength, which was imparted by my resin curing method and did wind up with a super strong material that could withstand any mechanical abuse I subjected it to with no specialized testing equipment. I am sure that with digital tech, modern fabrication techniques and polymer science, wood can become the dominant construction and fabrication material once again. It would be environmentally friendly (with a number of positive side-effects relating to carbon), simpler, easier to work with and easier to dispose of. Of course, it would be augmented in a minimal way by other familiar traditional materials at key points.

What's lignin?

If you ever have the desire to try this again, take a look at either a laminating or a penetrating epoxy with very low viscosity and an extra slow hardener. I think highly of the Proset stuff. Being able to take that period under vacuum from ~30 minutes to six hours makes a huge difference in how deep you can drive that stuff. There are also specific resins for wood stabilization (Cactus Juice), but they are not designed to give you that glassy look, so the effect would be very different.

Also, coming from a materials engineer here, I have never seen an epoxy mount come out with an optical surface. Like, ever. I am 100% positive at least one and more likely 2 (or six for that matter) of the surfaces on the sample in the paper have been polished. Even if they aren't doing it for visual effect, the first thing you would do with a mount like that is get it polished to go under an optical scope. If I was to try this in my lab, I might take the extra time to use a slightly thicker sample so I could be assured of polishing down to a perfect shape of the final product.

If you were to use a resin called LR White Resin with hardener you get better results as it has a viscosity of ~8 cps while the resin you were using has a viscosity of ~600 cps this will allow for deeper and quicker penetration of the resin into the wood piece. Also when you pull a vacuum on the resin embedded piece you should not allow the resin to boil but to slowly bubble. With this resin you you should place a piece of parafilm over the resin when drying as it will crack with exposure to oxygen, one way to eliminate oxygen exposure and not use parafilm is to leave the sample under vacuum overnight to harden.

A) I see you have a hard time to get your products in the wood. But why don't you use the "sap replacement process" (also called Boucherie process). You pressure-force the liquid by the butt of a pole, and it goes through the fibers following the natural path of sap.

It was quite difficult to find good references for this process, cf http://www.fao.org/3/an800e/an800e00.pdf on page 57, and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uUffe_kZYRc . My father did visit a factory some 50 years ago where they were treating telephone-line poles some 10 meters long this way, with creosote. With high pressure (I don't have the figures...), the liquid was pouring at the other end like through a hose... So, with a thicker resin, you should be able to go through at least tens of centimeters.



Then, after treatment, you could slice the pole in any thickness, and get full planks along the grain, which is the end goal if you want big surfaces of "wood glass".


B) I also see that you are afraid to fully dry the wood before injecting the epoxy, because you are much afraid of the shrinking. But I'm not sure that the resine+alcool is fully transparent. May be you could try 1) the transparency of just epoxy + 10% alcool, and 2) with a well-dryied plank, now that you can have some in any dimension...


C) did you try thin CA glue? it runs thinner than water and, if you can apply it it absence of moisture, you can choose when to start the hardening process by introducing the catalyser (either simple H2O or a dedicated hardener). Then even if you don't have the same final strengh as with epoxy, you can quickly test for the transparencey. My cheap provider of CA glue is hobbyking : 50g for less than 3$ : https://hobbyking.com/fr_fr/hobbyking-super-glue-ca-50g-1-7oz-super-thin.html ; check there also the "Insta-Set CA Accelerator".


D) may be you should try sandwiching the plank between 2 sheets of glass (covered with unmoulding coumpound?), and some weight on-top, during the hardening of the epoxy. This would avoid warping, the excess of resin over/below the plank, and a shiny surface whatever the roughness of the wood.

if you do consider doing this experiment in the future, it would be a good idea to look into vacuum bagging and release film, that way you can ensure that the wood stays flat for the entire curing process, removes air and excess resin, but also is able to be removed from the vacuum.

The epoxy bending like that could be due to an improper ratio of the two components. I don’t know about the one you used but most have to be measured by weight. Also you pouring them into separate containers first could leave different amounts of residue on the different containers screwing with the mixing ratio even further. The best practice here would be to put the container on a precise scale, set it to 0, add the exact amount of compound a, set it to 0 again and then add the exact amount of compound b. The epoxy simply needs to relatively match the refractive index of the wood fibers in order for to achieve translucency. If the refractive indices match perfectly, then you'll achieve transparency with some opacity based on the amount of defects within the material.

You can manipulate the refractive index with additives (such as other polymers or salts combined with miscible solvents) that do not significantly increase the viscosity of the solution. This will allow you to use a low concentration of polymer-to-solvent ratio to keep the desired refractive index and improve infiltration into the wood.

Also, never use weight/volume for anything. Always use weight/weight concentrations for greatest precision. Always convert the w/v% into wt% before making any solution.

In true composite manufacturing utilizing a vacuum you draw a vacuum from one side of the part and introduce the resin from the opposite side. This way you are able to insure no air is trapped as you force everything to travel from one side to the other. What if you were to take a long piece of wood cut length wise and pass the vacuum through one end of the wood and feed the resin from the other side. This way it would be like drawing the resin through a straw and you could guarantee the removal of any trapped foreign substances. Or at least you could use a vacuum bag so you not only have a vacuum drawing the resin in but you also have  the air pressure acting to to keep everything together and allow the resin to cure under vacuum.

I am not a scientist by any stretch of the imagination but, I understand wood. Wood is naturally under stress, every time you cut it, it releases some of that stress. The form, in which the wood takes after that stress is relieved is entirely based on the wood. That is why woodworkers start with larger pieces so they can make minor corrections (like planing or sanding) to keep the wood from twisting, bowing, and/or checking/cracking. The first problem with what you're doing is making stupidly thin pieces and removing the lignin, the glue, that keeps wood fibers together. Next problem is the resin infusing. Having the vacuum is a good start to draw out the air but, you need a pressure pot to force the resin back in simply because of the ethanol displacement in what is pretty much a sponge at this point. The final problem is curing. The best idea I could think of is a form fitted mold that can be sealed. That way, the resin can cure without the risk of the wood twisting, bowing, and/or checking/cracking. I don't know if any of this will work but, I figured it was worth a try.

Look for information about resin infusion, that is a method used for composite materials that ensures the epoxy or any resin you use to fill every gap in the substrate, for this kind of application, I would recommend to place the the pieces of wood between two sheets of mylar (regardless of the thickness) this will help getting an optical finish while keeping the part as flat as possible.

Another reason they likely call for that specific resin is the index of refraction. For the wood pieces to be clear in the end, you would want the saturating resin to have a matched index of refraction the surrounding cellulose

If I might make a suggestion.. Rather than a vacuum chamber at first you need something to pull the epoxy through the tubes like a straw. Think of how in early science classes when fresh cut flowers or celery is placed into a vase of colored water. Afterwards you can run the chamber to complete the process or if you were able to already fill it you can simply coat it. If you start out using the chamber while both sides of the straw are covered you can end up with air or other solutions trapped in the center. Another option instead of using a time curable epoxy would be a clear UV resin. That way you can give the resin time to fully penetrate, and only cure it by hitting it with UV light when you're ready. It's very similar to how hard wood veneer flooring is protected.

Few things to consider for next try:
- More porous wood - strength isn't really issue since it'll be soft during the process and hardens after the epoxy dries. Well, long as it stays together in processing.
- Test with burl wood? Or cutting the wood at angle against the grain. Sacrifice transparency for more structural strength so the pieces wouldn't break during boiling etc?
- Wondering if during the epoxy soaking in vacuum the piece could be held in the epoxy by a wire mesh or similar - so the epoxy is properly covering every side.
- Flat drying until epoxy hardens to workable soft rubbery state,
- then let the piece dry properly clamped between glass sheets or similar flat hard surfaces that won't stick to it. Some mold release stuff may be necessary still..
- Even less viscous epoxy, or play around with the mixing ratios? In my limited experience that may give more time to vacuum before the epoxy starts to harden.
- Working with other casted materials; vacuum the epoxy before pouring it in container with the pieces. Probably minor improvement, if any visible change at all.

you should definitely try that one again. don't use  sodium hydroxide/sulfate and peroxide, instead you should opt for the acidified sodium chlorite and sodium hydroxide version commonly known as the Jayme-Wise method (and thousands of modifications thereof). you can enhance the speed of the method by using a ultrasonic bath if you have one. as for the drying at the end you should not remove the water and freeze-dry the woodpieces instead. in that way the structure will remain intact only removing all the water. i know the original article was about making good composite material and for that hardwood is probably better but if transparency is the goal softwood should probably work better since the structure is more regular and cell lumen are bigger on average.

What might have happened if you had sandwiched the wood, fresh with epoxy, between two pieces of extra thin glass or plastic?   Just like preparing slides to be used with a microscope.  Squeeze out the excess epoxy and weigh it down during the curing process to prevent cupping.

Wood naturally "straightens" as it is dried and seasoned so you would need to find properly kiln dried then seasoned (min 5 years) wood, cut many samples then leave further to season and hope that you will get some that are straight enough.
After cutting tension is released and some pieces will bend more than others - you need to leave them to season for long enough for that process to take place.
Basswood is readily available for building instruments and I suspect the authors of the paper used it for that very reason - because it was easy to acquire a sample that has been sufficiently seasoned and probably procured it from a Luthier already cut to size.
Good luthiers hold their own stock and often have wood seasoned for easily 20 years.
Most people are familiar only with the kind of wood intended for home construction which is a whole different paradigm or with furniture making where instead of seasoning for very long times everything is made from multiple pieces glued together in such a manner where the tension in one piece is balanced by the tension in the opposite one.

If you want to avoid as much bending as possible you need to ideally buy wood intended for making acoustic instrument tops.

Suggestion in drawing the vacuum. Put the piece of resin soaked wood in a plastic bag. Place between two pieces of glass to keep it from bending, and then pull the vacuum on the plastic bag. Just remember to vacuum trough a catch vessel or trap so that you do not end up with a lot of epoxy in your pump. That will not be so nice. A sharp ripping[all flat ground and high hook] or a combo blade[flat and beveled teeth 1+2 or 1+4] and proper feed speed will greatly improve your wood cuts, the slow feed you used burns the wood. For a 10 inch ripping saw blade 16-30 teeth, it looks like you have a 40-50t cross cut blade on there.[adjust proportionally for actual blade diameter] (brand also makes a difference, freude CMT tenryu are all good and re-sharpenable several times)
Keep your epoxy cold to slow the crosslinking, high end composites are often made with "pre-preg" which is fabric pre-impregnated with a specific proportion of resin under controlled factory conditions and then stored and shipped in a freezer with weeks to months shelf life. The Specific resins are selected with consideration for curing temperature and generally need curing conditions elevated above room temperature for practical set times. And most are post-cured at hot temperatures; maybe 40-50c for initial cure(important not to get hot spots here, it is exothermic and the main polymerization has an ideal temp) followed a day or two later by several hours at 70-110c [depending on the exact product]. The post cure greatly increases strength, but not just by accelerating the final bits of cross linking, as the strength from a high temp post cure is higher that that achieved with several weeks of moderate temperature aging.
Lastly most structural composites are made under pressure, the vacuum cycling you used is a step in that direction but the next step is to bag the item with a special multi layer bag and draw a vacuum to compress the item (somewhat like vacuum bagged foods) and reduce resin and void content. The most advanced insert the whole bagged item into an autoclave at 2-3 atmospheres. The bag layers are an inner perforated film that allows both air and excess resin through but is generally anti-stick a middle scrim that allows the flow of air and may also absorb some excess resin and then the outer layer is a solid film that is air tight and contains the vacuum valve/hose attachment.
Higher production items may use close tolerance molds with precisely weighed materials[no excess resin to absorb] and mechanical pressure on the mold halves rather than bagging.

You should try degassing the resin before adding it to the wood. You might also benefit from looking into different ways of reducing the resin with a solvent. Usually the datasheet of resins will specify if there is an acceptable or specific solvent to use for this. Sometimes there are also options for controlling the flash and cure properties of the catalyst, although this is usually more common with polyurethane clear coats that are used in much larger quantities and environments where they need to be perfected.

You might also try a vacuum bagging process where you draw the resin across the wood in a controlled manner. That's one popular way structural carbon fiber composites are done when dry fabrics are used for the composite layup.

BTW, I painted cars and did custom graphics for many years. When it comes to getting a polished surface. The standard is to smooth the surface with 1500 grit wet sandpaper. Use a bucket of water with a couple drops of dish soap like (or specifically) Palmolive to clean the paper and surface as you go. Follow this up with 2000 grit, then 2500 grit in the same wet sanding process. Be sure to completely remove the scratches from each prior step. Then use 3M Perfect-it 2 polish compound on a heavy foam polishing pad with a polishing machine set to around 1000-1200rpm. The trick is to remember the compound does the work. Never let the working surface go dry while never adding too much polish that it gets slung off the pad. The surface will begin to get warm if the pad is doing the work instead of the compound. Also, never sand through the epoxy to the surface underneath. This is harder to do on the edges where the epoxy is thinner. All polishing steps must stay in the epoxy layer. To use wet/dry sandpaper, tear it in strips in a size you like (2-5"×9-11") and fold it in thirds. Let dry paper soak in water/soap mix for 10-30min before use too. This will soften the folded corners of the sandpaper and prevent them from causing deeper scratches than the specific grit.
If you sand by hand, always sand like your hand is the x-axis of a cnc machine - left and right. If you sand with the direction of your fingers you will create an uneven surface. The pro way is to use a soft foam block that is designed for backing up sandpaper, but I have a collection of ~50 blocks for all the different applications and preferences. For small things, you don't need this just use your hand. Perfect-it 2 polish is the best machine polish for transitioning from sand paper scratches to a polished plastic. It isn't really a finishing compound. For instance, if you use it on a black car it will leave a haze and swirls on the surface. This type of compound is usually followed by a medium and light machine compound to get an absolutely perfect finish, but these depend on the application. With light colors like silver or white cars the final finish can often be achieved with just Perfect-it 2 because of how light reflects off the surface. There is a Perfect-it 3 compound too but I never liked it as much as 2. Most compounds tend to have fillers that deceptively make the surface look better at first while the job isn't really done. They are basically filled with oils that make the surface look okay at a glance. In my experience Perfect-it 2 does tbe best job of creating a truly perfect surface ready for the next step without artificially hiding problems or burning/damaging the surface.

I think you were also on the right track with the glass dish cured product. Carbon fiber composites sold in flat sheets are usually made with the cosmetic side formed against a sheet of glass. You would probably benefit from a cheap and flatter piece of glass from the hardware store.

The pathways are largely 1 way; so that if you want to try this, it's important to locate this direction & ensure that during the doping process has the correct end exposed. Offhand, I would assume that the end closest to the ground (when a tree) is the best to have submerged & the upper end towards the vacuum source.

Next, you are correct that your vacuum source matters here, it needs to rapidly drop the pressure & the chamber should be as small as possible.

You should also find a better epoxy that's still clear & chemically suitable but has a longer cure time, min double the process time. You want it to still be fully uncured until you are done the vacuum stage. You are better off with overkill vacuum work then even slightly underkill.

You can use a mold, but either way make certain that the surface is rigid, flat & easy to remove. Avoid floppy molds.

Once you have an initial cure (solid without full strength) put some kind of weight on top to ensure that it does not twist or otherwise deform itself.

You are very correct that a lot has to do with the thickness of the initial wood, I was thinking that the thin wood strips used for various laminates maybe a place to start. Either way, you can make far thinner slices, just a bit of practice, proper tool use & fine blades.

All said, I'm curious about the results that could be achieved using laminate wood layers as source & various cementious agents similar to fiberglass, carbon fiber, etc.

Try this & you should be able to do this right; I don't think predrying is a good idea, you can remove all the ethanol under vacuum & you don't risk the structural integrity as in the absence of the replacement agent.

Alternatively, consider the issue facing the inventors of aerogels, perhaps a freeze drying method would allow the structural integrity to be preserved despite dehydration.

So instead of trying to pull the epoxy through the piece all at once with a high power vacuum, you should try to slow down the epoxy impregnation step.

After you've pulled all the obvious water out of a piece of wood with alcohol, slowly start adding one of the two parts to the piece of wood and soaking it in that. If the Alcohol you're using is a solvent for the epoxy, this will allow the epoxy resin a larger amount of time to penetrate down into the piece of wood. Since it's a two part epoxy it shouldn't start hardening until you add the second part of the epoxy, which you can do as a single large dose of the second part.

After that, with the hydrogen peroxide boil/bleaching, you could use ammonia or ammonium hydroxide. Ammonia softens cellulose and hemicellulose, so that would allow the bleaching agent easier penetration into the wood, but it might darken the cellulose.

Interesting to a point, but backing away a few steps to consider an overview: The only way a truly clear material will result is if the refractive index of the remaining fibers matches that of the permeating resin. Thin fiberglass layers can be nearly clear, as the glass fibers in resin minimize scattering of light, and though highly translucent the glass adds dramatic strength that the grossly denatured wood fibers have lost by the time the process has broken down cross-linking, and pulled out opaque tannins, natural dyes, etc. Manufacturing modern polymers and cheap glass fiber cloth is likely far easier and cheaper, and less environmentally adverse when done under EPA/OSHA standards, than trying to basically turn a perfectly good material like wood into something it is not - clear. So, aside from the curiosity side of this, there are lots of videos showing shop-level resin impregnating success for woodturning etc. which let wood look like wood, yet gain dramatic strength. I hate when TV "decorators" paint any decent wood surface, and similarly, I see no value in losing the aesthetic property of wood to make some other less aesthetic end product, especially if the goal is to make the final result no longer recognizable as wood. Early plastics mimicked natural material like tortoiseshell, and helped save the turtle populations; no one tried to make real tortoiseshell clear to emulate ordinary plastic. The epoxy cure phase should have used mold release treated "peel Ply" on each side of the epoxy soaked piece and then a weighted plate glass atop another plate glass as a sandwich. Using the peel ply would keep the sandwich from being permanently bonded to the wood. Disassembly  includes peeling back the peel ply for reasonably flat optical surfaces This also would have squeezed more epoxy out, for a thinner composite.

Suggestions for improvement:

of cause use withwide cuts.

after sodiumhydroxide/sodiumsulfite step wash ist two or three times more.

after peroxide and washing, use a dehydration cycle :

(each step about an hour and liquid/material-ratio about 50x)

50% ethanol - 75% ethanol - 95% ethanol - 3x fresh 99% ethanol (absolute alcohol) (maybe an extra 3x Xylene - if it dilutes epoxy more efficient) (like tissue processing in a histokinette)

prevacuum the epoxy and finally another vacuum as you did with the epoxy-wood (remove air out of wood). let it soak a while and put it in fresh bubblefree epoxy (de-alcoholize it). repeat as much as possible. keep it liquid as long as possible.

precool the mold and fill in a thin layer of bubblefree epoxy an let it preharden slightly, lay in the warm epoxy soaked piece of wood an let it harden a bit more and finally coat it with more warm bubblefree epoxy. (duration by expertise)

I see a few possible issues here:

* The curving can be due to the fact that you took a piece ont he edge of the tree, while the paper could have took the center of the tree.

* The wood may not be really lengthwise, but at some angle. In fact, this appear to be the issue, look at the darker grow ring, it appear quite wide, should have been more narrow, which make me think it was at an angle.

* Heating the epoxy at the third vaccum, if time allow, would make it more liquid, but make it set quite faster. A balance of heating and quick set may work.

* I beleive that using less hardener cause the reaction to be slower, which may allow the epoxy to fill in more. There is also some chemicals to slow it down.

* Today's wood is also not the same as 50 years ago. Today everything is quick growth...

I think I know why it's bending...

The outer layer will be hardening first, which means the surface shrinks while the inside is still pliable. This causes the outer layer to curve towards the most dried areas (the outer layers) while the middle conforms due to still being not completely cured.

I'm not quite sure how you would solve this. The only thing I can think is using a lot of resin, completely covering it, then abrading the epoxy down until you hit the wood. This way, the epoxy should have completely dried on the outside, preventing the entire piece from warping. This would also solve the issue with surface texture as you can polish it up.

My other suggestion would be to make sure the wood slices are completely smooth before treating them, as any deviation in the length of the grain might cause this kind of deviation too, due to epoxy not completely penetrating the wood before it starts curing.

10:20 - I think it took a lot of washings because there just wasn't enough water. Generally, whatever you're trying to rinse out is going to distribute itself evenly among all of the water, both inside the wood and outside of it. So if a third of the water in your beaker is in the wood, then no matter how long you leave it to soak, only about two thirds of that stuff is going to leak out of the wood.

This is one reason that when a cook is making stock, they'll use a lot of water for the extraction process and then boil it down later, rather than just aiming to have the desired volume by the end of the extraction. And it's also why the ingredients are removed before boiling down. The less water they use, the more of the stuff they're trying to extract will stay in the ingredients. And if the ingredients are left in the stock while reducing, as the concentration of the stock increases, a portion of that goodness will diffuse back into the ingredients.

Another analogy would be using a towel to dry a rug. The towel is not going to take all of the water out of the rug. Rather, the best you can do is get the towel and the rug to be "equally wet", so to speak. So a smaller towel means a wetter rug. You'll have to wring out the towel more times to get the job done.

Procedures I'd Attempt

1. The video only shows two different grain cuts. The third grain cut is singularly diagonal to the grain. The fourth grain cut is doubly diagonal to the grain. Slice the wood diagonally across the grain in both directions. This would mean that the wood has tube openings on all six sides of the treated piece. This involves some serious measurements to obtain the most porous borders capable by the wood. The diagonal arrangements of the wood tubes only extend the tubes about half as much, but their orientation retains rigidity through the rest of the procedures. Thoroughly sand the wood piece for smooth edges and sides.

2. Use the same chemical mixture as described in the video. Place one piece (not a bundle) of wood in the chemical bath.

3. Heat the chemical mixture and soaked wood piece.

4. Once heated, place the hot mixture and wood piece in the vacuum chamber to completely saturate the wood with the chemical mixture.

5. Once the air is pulled out of the wood, remove the first chemical solution and wood from the vacuum chamber. Pour off the chemical bath.

6. Apply as many water rinses as needed until the saturated wood no longer colors the water.

7. Allow the piece of wood to dry.

8. In a fresh water rinse, place the chemically saturated wood in the vacuum. This should color the water with the trapped chemical within the wood and extract air from the wood.

9. Allow the piece of wood to dry.

10. Apply the original second chemical mixture (not bleach) to the wood piece.

11. Add heat to the second chemical mixture to open the pores of the wood to saturate with the second chemical.

12. After appropriate heat is applied, place the heated wood piece and second chemical mixture into the vacuum chamber.

13. Once the air within the wood is extracted and the second chemical mixture thoroughly penetrates the wood piece, remove from the vacuum.

14. Apply as many water rinses as needed until the saturated wood no longer colors the water.

15. Allow the piece of wood to dry.

16. In a fresh water rinse, place the second chemically saturated wood piece in the vacuum. This should color the water with the trapped second chemical within the wood and extract air from the wood.

17. While the wood is still wet and pliable with water, apply the resin mixture in a flexible plastic (not rubber) mold.

18. Place the resin mixture and wood piece in the vacuum chamber. Keep the vacuum applied until the resin sets but not hardens completely.

19. Remove the set resined wood piece from the vacuum chamber and let it dry completely.

20. Once completely dry, do not pry the dried piece of wood from the mold. Instead cut away the flexible plastic mold from the finished piece. Use an eyeglass cleaner cloth to shine all exteriors of the resined wood piece.

The results of these procedures should yield better results in strength, clarity, saturation of the resin, and finished shape of the resin.

There is epoxy specifically designed to be used in a vacuum chamber. There is a facet of woodworking where you work with something that is known as a stabilized blank. You immerse the piece of wood in the stabilizing epoxy and then pull a vacuum to remove all of the air and water from the piece of wood. The epoxy doesn't cure in the chamber and is meant to be used over and over again. You cure the epoxy by baking the impregnated wood. It essentially turns the wood into a plastic.

I used to make earrings pendants, rings and charms with this process and I used even thicker slices of wood and unlike other videos I've seen on YouTube, You've gotten the closest to my (not so secret) method. The one reason I was able to not only get it as clear as what you did here, but with thicker wood samples is the extra time with the vacuum chamber.
1.) Unlike most others... you actually notice the increase in volume when adding something to a measured volume of anything else (Adding anything to 500 would be over 500) <-- common sense isn't common ! <GOOD CALL>
2.) I got the Sodium Sulfite and Sodium Hydroxide to a boil and after half an hour I gave it a brake from the heat and put it in the vacuum chamber to get as much of the air out of it as possible. I pumped the air out and let it back in then returned it to the heat for another half hour. I did this three times to make sure it was soaked all the way through and the mixture can reach the lignin at the innermost parts of the wood.
3.) after I cleaned it all out and it was ready to be placed in resin I placed it in the vacuum chamber a fourth time but with RO/DI Water and a few drops of a latex paint to give them a tint when finished.
4.) When placing it in the resin I started with a flat mold and let a 1/16th inch layer dry at the bottom with the wood pieces placed on top (not pushed in to it) that will give the mold a flat base AND hold the wood down so it won't float to the top while it's setting.
5.) I used slow setting epoxy because to remove all of the air bubbles you'll need to vacuum it and let the air back in at least three times so you're replacing all the air bubbles with the epoxy deep inside the layers of wood. That and heating it up with a heat gun between vacuums takes more time than you'd think.
6.) at least 24 hours later, pop it out of the mold and using a dremel, starting off with 400-grit sandpaper, work your way up to a glass finish.

Try cactus resin.  It is a vacuum chamber safe stabilizing resin.  It lets you leave the wood held down under the resin in a vacuum chamber for several hours while all the remaining air, or in this case alcohol gets pulled out.  You then let the air back in the chamber which allows the resin to be soaked into the wood.  After which you remove it carefully and bake it to set it.  Hope that helps.

1.) If you stick to this epoxy, I'd use a silicone mat that would lay flat on a piece of glass pane. It makes it easier to peel off but still should hold it level.
2.) I'd recommend you use "Cactus Juice". It is a water-like resin used to stabilize wood, a.k.a replace all the air in the wood with resin. (Yes, it was allready mentioned in the comments, still wanted to mention it)
3.) When I bleach wood, I use a 30-35% hydrogen peroxide solution with a couple drops of 30% ammonium cloride as an acivator.

two steps that should fix your end issues: (not trying to sound conceited, just some ideas from my resin stabilized wood turning projects i make for a living)
- when your laying the pieces out to dry/cure place them into a pressure chamber (about 60 psi) and add additional epoxy on top. this will force epoxy into the wood better than the vacuum chamber which was only pulling resin into the piece where air once was in a "replacement" type exchange.
- once fully cured, sand the bottom of the finished piece until you reach the actual wood, then re-polish this surface. this will eliminate the problem with the wood being raised off the print of the paper your trying to view.

I wonder if the use of vacuum impregnation would work. This is used in manufacturing where the form is made up with the glass fibre etc. and a flexible plastic 'bag' is carefully fitted over it. A vacuum is pulled making sure the bag does not have wrinkles in it. The epoxy is then allowed to enter at one or more points under strict control. This ensures that the epoxy is drawn through the material and minimises air bubbles. It also gives a very high quality finish. I suspect that the epoxy has a long handling time, and that the product would have to be left to cure for a long time. I also think it would be possible to ensure the pieces would remain flat it holing them between two pieces of ply or midfield, held by a static weight.  Just a thought.

I think the bending could have been partially due to the thinner wood slices. I wonder if covering the samples with a book after the samples cured enough not to be sticky would help impose a flatter form in the final piece.

I also think the 8% peroxide solution would work better than the 3%, if not preheated and slowly brought to a low boil. If you dont prewash so vigorously, or use slightly thicker pieces (like in the first batch), the sodium hydroxide and sodium sulfide solution will soak more into the center of the thicker wood slivers, which I think you're right in assuming will help the hydrogen peroxide step.

I think the molds are a good idea, but perhaps it could be improved. Letting the piece partially cure, then covering it with another layer of partially cured apoxy is a great method. To get the pieces to cure flat, maybe using a second silicon mold, stacked on top (like one fits cups together in a stack) and filling the top mold with some sand or something of decent mass after the apoxy becomes viscous enough to not squeeze out, might also help keep the cured mold flat in the plane of the wood. This flat silicone mold on top might also help maintain a smooth finish on the plane of the wood after curing.

I really think the first run would have been just about perfect, as far as apoxy fill is concerned, at least, with the new vacuum pump. The bubbling was much more vigorous, and may have allowed you to try a 4th or 5th vacuum cycle to see if that helped with the apoxy back fill.

In any case, awesome experiment! Sort of reminds me of that chemist/taxidermist/mortician who invented plastination of animal and human flesh (pretty grotesque, I know). I'll never forget being 12 years old seeing his exhibition at the boston museum of science; there were thin slices of plastic filled blood vessels and muscle fiber which you could likewise read text through. If memory serves, he had some super complicated process that involved removing the liquid water from cellular plasma while simultaneously replacing it with some plastic or apoxy like resin, probably in a vacuum chamber. I think it involved salt or something, I cant imagine how gentile of a process that must be to dry out cells withough bursting the membrane and making a plastic solution with low enough molecular size and low enough viscosity to make it through the cell membeains without damaging them. It worked well enough to preserve hair thin nerve endings and nervous system stems as one complete piece. Wasnt for the weak of heart though, gave me nightmares for quite a while 😭

Would using UV resin be out of the question? A big problem seems to be the vacuum can only be cycled on a few times because the resin starts hardening, but UV resin shouldn't do so until UV light is applied. Unless I'm missing something, it sounds like it could help.

Also, if you heated the UV resin a bit and let it sit for a while the bubbles would float away, potentially receding the possibility that some air gets trapped in the cellulose and keeps the resin from entering.

EDIT: Oh, another idea. You could let it sit in the resin without removing it into the glass for hardening to ensure the full surface area of the wood is covered by resin to spare. To get rid of this extra resin, you could sand the excess after it hardens with fine sandpaper until you're close to the surface of the wood. This would introduce irregularities that would diffuse light. If then you apply a thin layer of resin directly, say with a piece of cloth, the irregularities would disappear and you'd restore the non-diffusing surface.

So we do a process at university where we wet fiberglass and carbon fiber in a similar way. We will use a table to form the shape of the fibers and have a hole in the bottom with a hose going down into a vat of the epoxy. Then we cover the whole top of the table in thin plastic, we call is saran wrap but its thicker. Then we use a "bridge" of porous material under the saran wrap to allow the epoxy to move up the hose across to the fibers and out a small hole we cut in the saran wrap. We attach our pump to the hole and seal the entire thing. Once we turn on the oump the epoxy is drawn out of the vat, across the bridges and through the part. This allows us to directionalize the flow of the epoxy and push the air (and any other stuff, ethanol in your case) out. Then we let it sit for a few hours till the epoxy sets, which might be what they mean in the paper and might be evidence that they used a similar process in the paper. Just make sure you have a catch basin so you dont get epoxy in the pump.

One thing I'd try with this is using a pressure pot instead of a vacuum chamber. I know some epoxy-like curing liquids extract gasses much more efficiently in pressure than in a vacuum. Pressure may also help with the pieces with the longer tubes, to push the resin towards the center.
And while this experiment is interesting, what actual use would clear wood have? It's not great optically and all the structure is dependent on the resin; and the resin itself has good optical characteristics and is structurally stable enough by itself. I just don't see the point of 'clear' wood other than being able to say you made wood that's somewhere between translucent and transparent.
I think this is more of a scientific art experiment that some scientists or students had a random idea for with no practical purpose, but with a 'why not try it' reason to experiment.
I also feel that resin is almost cheating, because you're depending on the resin to be clear and have optical qualities, not the wood itself. Put the wood in translucent blue resin, and suddenly you have translucent blue wood. All this is is removing color from the wood; to maybe add a wood grain look to resin, with added depth, like a 3D grain?
I don't think results would change much between species and hardness of woods, they're all similar in structure, so there's no reason to believe there would be large changes in the process other than amounts and strengths of solutions and times.

Although, if you could scale this up to pieces of wood that you buy from the lumber store, and make it work flawlessly, clear wood furniture could be interesting; though I still have doubts, costs would be high, and you'd have to bond pieces like they're glass rather than traditional woodworking. But then again, it's back to the argument of adding a 3D wood grain look to the end product rather than making wood clear, and there's probably simpler, more economical ways of attempting that.

Tips from someone who has worked with large amounts of resin, it's usually better to let large blobs of resin harden if the surface is a "shiny" plastic/glass surface (or treated with release agents), that way you can just peel/pop off the blobs, the key point is to have as little surface roughness as possible as that would otherwise provide excellent grip for the resin.

Another tip is to try and get your hands on some vinyl ester, their viscosities are in general much lower and that way you could probably displace more air and ethanol (and you can use modifiers to easily tweak gel times).

This specific epoxy seems to be either quite shitty or mixed in a wrong way (this isn't as easy as it seems - you need to follow the resin/hardener ratio and mix it in two different cups sequentially). Always test your mixing ratio by heating it up - it speeds up curing process and tells you if it will actually be able to fully harden and keep its shape. Try UV-curing polyester (Solarez, for example) resin that hardens under UV light so degassing/soaking cycle can be repeated virtually unlimited number of times. Definitely, cross-cut pieces of wood should be used. To get a better edge without crushed fibers, it has to be sanded with a fresh fine sandpaper and cleaned with compressed air to remove dust. Giving it to an experienced woodworker who can clean it with a sharp low-angle hand plane also helps.

Good video. There's one step that I can offer from resin casting projects I've researched that might help you quite a bit to get better penetration of the epoxy into the wood. After pulling the vacuum and letting the air back into the chamber, switch it to a pressure vessel and run it up to 45-60psi for a minute or two. If you have a good source of air for this, it shouldn't add that much time to the process between the multiple runs of pulling a vacuum. For resin castings, this is particularly useful as it crushes air bubbles caught in the form and any gas bubbles generated as the epoxy cures, but it also forces the resin deeper into any nooks and fine details of the form. In theory, this should push the resin further into the capillaries of the wood. I saw a few other people suggest cactus juice, which would be a good thing to try as well, though it is a thermal set resin and will require baking the wood, so not sure if that will do anything to discolor this highly processed wood.

Probably most of your problems come from the rough surface. Sand it with sandpaper 80, 180, 280, 320, 400, 600, 1000, 1500 and 2000 than polish with Al2O3 1 micrometer (standard metallographic technique) and you will have a good result.

look into how tissue is processed for diagnostics. They sometimes use resin to harden the tissue before it goes to a microtome to slice into 1 micron slices... but the normal processing uses paraffin. The steps are usually.. soak tissue in formalin to preserve the cells from decay, then gradually remove the water using graded  reagent alcohols... usually starting at 70%, then 80% then 95 % then 100%. The alcohol is then flushed out with xylene, usually 2 or 3 stages under vacuum. some heat can be used to help remove the alc. then the tissue is infiltrate with liquid paraffin. once this is completed, the tissue is moved to a mould where it can be held in a vice on a microtome to make the very thin slices .5 to 5 microm slices to be viewed under a microscope.... those slices are very transparent... In the resin method I think they use acetone before the resin and not xylene.  (I work in the anatomical pathology field repairing this equipment that does these procedures)

1. Use a slow set finishing epoxy. Something clear, but that takes many hours to set.
2. Heat the epoxy. Just warming it up 15 degrees makes it like water it's so viscous. It'll soak the wood faster.
2.5. vacuum your epoxy in the cup after heating but before pouring: just to help pull bubbles.
3. Once poured with the wood floating, leave the vacuum on for a minute or more, and then draw out the letting air back in for like 30 sec. Drawing this process out will put less pressure on the epoxy but for a much longer time, letting it capillary up in there
4. Cut your wood thinner. 2mm, 1mm, etc. Will help like everything.
5. Cut it really slowly and in a single direction to make a nice surface on both sides.
6. Lightly sand both ends, but beware using course grit will just fold over and plug all the cellulose tubes.
7. Air compressor blow the sides of the peices to blow any surface dust and shit away
8. When you lay out the peices, place them between two peices of the flattest glass you have (mirrors, picture frames etc) to put an optically clear flat surface on both sides but without all the excess glue blob on top.

A few alterations to try...Instead of only working with the end grain, revisit the long grain pieces. If you make a silicone funnel out of caulk slightly smaller in size as the treated piece will be, you can use its elasticity to clamp onto the piece fairly softly. Then, feed the epoxy into the end of the grain structure and allow gravity to carry it further inside which potentially eliminates the need for the vacuum since gravity and the epoxy's viscosity should force everything out of the grain structure. You would also have curing taking place on all sides to mitigate warp, and suspending it above a soda bottle allows you to easily catch the waste to put back into the funnel or easily discard. The funnel would be easy to clean and remove with its flexibility, too.

I think it might be a good idea to try it with different epoxies.  It might be worth switching to a slightly more viscous one if the cure time (or at least the set time, during which it remains liquid) is significantly longer, to give you more time to pull epoxy into the wood.  You might also try experimenting with different methods for pulling the epoxy in, such as setting the wood on a strong mesh (for support), pouring epoxy over it then creating a vacuum only on the underside of it, using atmospheric pressure to force the epoxy through the tubes and into the microstructure of the wood.

At the end of the video you said the purpose of the wood was to strengthen the epoxy, but I think there are other better materials than wood that might still be transparent and a lot easier to work with:
Bleached paper towel
Any non-dyed synthetic fabrics (nylon, rayon, polyester, etc)
Fiberglass insulation strands combed perpendicular to the final flat surface (bed of nails and a brush)
A controlled break of tempered glass joined back together with the epoxy (possibly multiple sheets of cracked tempered glass layered over each other). For the controlled break, I think applying and curing epoxy to one side of the glass then chipping an edge of the glass would keep the shards together. Then pulling another batch of epoxy into the cracks with a vacuum chamber to restore transparency. The result might be a variation of laminated safety glass with worse UV resistance.

Dry leaves - not necessary, but they seem to work faster than fresh/wet ones
10%/2,5M NaOH solution - bathe leaves for week or two in room temperature, I use flat but large area plastic containers (yes, it's the same concentration as in Your vid, just with NaOH. Not sure about Na2SO3 but if You have leftovers then may try it too)

The optical properties remind me of Ulexite a naturally occuring rock with a fiber optic structure.

"Ulexite is also known as TV rock due to its unusual optical characteristics. The fibers of ulexite act as optical fibers, transmitting light along their lengths by internal reflection. When a piece of ulexite is cut with flat polished faces perpendicular to the orientation of the fibers, a good-quality specimen will display an image of whatever surface is adjacent to its other side."

Lovely effort. Here is my two cents reflecting a few other comments below:
Sodium hypochlorite, yes. Wash out with distilled with cycles of vacuum between change outs. Wash the H2O with anhydrous alcohol. IPA ok. Again, vacuum cycle this with change outs, but then raise to boiling fully submerged. Weigh down with a large heave ptfe stir bar etc. Without drying, dump the alcohol and top off with a heat or UV cure expoy thinned to less than 100cps. Again, vacuum & weighed down in the resin. The alcohol will vaporize if it can see the vacuum. Diffusion will take the remainder. Pull the samples and sandwich in FEP film, polymerize normally. One additional step we found interesting was to press the samples after impregnation and before polymerization perpendicular to grain. Best luck!

Another way to dry the wood would be to use ethanol baths, then 50:50 ethanol:acetone. It dries the wood without causing shrinkage, as acetone has a lower surface tension. The result with cross-cut wood is not exactly transparent, but a bunch of optical fibers. That is why the text is clear when it is in contact with the flat wood surface, in spite of the wood being 2-3mm thick, but gets blurred when there is even a thin space between wood and paper.


To make the result maximally transparent, the index of refraction (IR) of the filling resin should match that of the cellulose in the wood. It is unlikely that they match by coincidence. Maybe there is some transparent material that can be mixed with the resin to adjust its IR?


A fiber-optic, if not transparent, material should be possible with cross-cut wood by replacing the resin with paraffin, or clarified beeswax. (I got the latter by heating a mix of beeswax and activated carbon at 120 C or more and filtering the hot liquid through a paper towel.)
I could see these "wood-epoxy" panels work quite well in a sort of "bulls eye" panel. Lets light through but not wind.

What if rather than using a vacuum chamber, you used a pressure chamber? Rather than pulling the air out and relying on the resin rushing in, you use the pressure to shrink the air bubbles to nearly nothing while simultaneously pushing in the resin. You can even let it cure under pressure for potentially even better results.

I feel like I might be giving up academic secrets, but when you're trying to reproduce a paper's method and something isn't clear, email the authors, but DON'T go to the PI. The actual experimental work is done by grad students or postdocs and they are usually happy to briefly talk about their work as long as you come across as professional and not needing hand-holding. Email the first or second author, or the corresponding author if one is called out, and they will probably at least give you a few quick answers. Their workload is huge, though, so you might not get a response.

You could try sandwiching the cutting between two thin layers of transparent plastic, such as cellophane or clear projection film sheets. You'd likely end up with a minimal epoxy layer, and as it terminates to the very smooth and transparent plastic, you wouldn't have to worry about the surface. Nor about peeling, and you'd get away with very little resin if need be, and the surfaces wouldn't be exposed to air at all which might affect the difference in curing time between the surfaces, which i think leads to the curving. You could probably use some mechanical pressure (such as a book) while curing to prevent any disformations. You might also experiment with curing temperatures - as far is i know most epoxies harden faster when heated way above room temperature. Could also be the curvature culprit.
