If you research this concept further you'll find it was pioneered by BRE/TRADA (UK) in the 1980's. There was a limited commercial offshoot using Urea Resorcinol Formaldehyde and Beech. Both the delignification and impregnation was done at high temp's with vacuum/pressure cycles. The prototype plant they used was a modified preservative impregnation system. The end product was highly impact resistant longitudinally, and easy to machine. Sheet steel stretch-forming was one area of use. Of course URF isn't transparent, so not as sensational :)

For me this is a case study in how a lot of science is becoming driven by university press release and expectation of media clickbait stories on publication. Take a mediocre, extremely limited process, tweak the shit out of it so you get maybe one or two good results, post a vague experimental process, and voila: "Stunning endless possibilities for invisible wood, the eco-friendly material of the future!" headlines everywhere. In fact, the process is incredibly finicky, not at all "eco-friendly", relatively poor in terms of structural and UV exposure characteristics, and will never appear for sale on store shelves anywhere. But the lab that did it gets headlines the world over, massive publicity for the university, and so the research $ keep flowing to them. It's really quite disreputable I think. Thanks for showing us how the sausage is made.

@5:25 when you topped off the water level to get your concentration, using a beaker level mark is very inaccurate. You should have started with about 2/3 of the volume you needed in distilled water, transferred the solution to a graduated cylinder, rinsed the beaker with distilled water 3 times, and brought the level up to 500mL in the cylinder.

This procedure looks to be a little forgiving on the exact concentrations, but in the future you can make more accurate concentrations using this method.

I have sliced  pieces of fat lighter thin and got very translucent slabs about 4-5mm  that had significant strength because the pine resin is more pliable than cured epoxy.   the  long grain slabs , by having both ends submerged  are trapping  material in the center,  would work better with only one end in epoxy.   in total  cellulose reinforces epoxy with transparency and possibly polarizing properties  wold better be achieved  by the paper making process. think oiled paper  if one were able to realign the fibers electrostatically or chemically somehow it could be less distorted   but never achieving optical clear .

About the spacing-from-the-paper issue - I'm thinking - the cellulose structures seem to act as tubes. The (transparent) epoxy basically fills out the tubes and the in-between spaces to form light-pipes (similar to a bunch of optic fibers mushed together). Any light that enters one end will leave the other end. Only, if there is a gap, the light will no longer be collimated and you'd see a blurred image instead of being able to read the text. The cellulose is not transparent at all, in and of itself; it's merely the geometric structure that allows the transparent epoxy to form light-pipes. (This also explains why the blurriness when the wood doesn't extend all the way to the surface of the epoxy)

Hi Nile, with your thoughts on the NaOH and peroxide @26:51, you are pretty much right. Industrially, peroxide oxidative bleaching is carried out at an alkaline pH since it drives the reaction of H2O2 > H+ + HOO to the right. The HOO- ion is what oxidizes the residual lignin and pitch in the wood. Maximum brightness gain (max elimination of lignin) is achieved at pH = 10.5. Not sure if your peroxide has something alkaline in it but without the residual NaOH the pH might have been lower.

But I might have some possible improvements:
-sand off/prevent any burn marks on the untreated wood
->the discoloration (carbon I guess) seems to stay
-sand and polish the finished product to make the sample as thin as possible (regarding the added thickness from the epoxy)
->thicker material means more fraction of the light
-try to keep the samples as flat as possible maybe add a top layer to the mold to force it into level form
-> the curvature makes the piece act like a lens (a really bad one at that)
-you could build small frames (from acrylic, or something like that) to reinforce the wood during the procedure
-use less hardener for the epoxy to be able to make more vacuum cycles
->will give you a longer working time but it also can affect the "clearness" of the epoxy so a test would be good
-put the mixed epoxy into a vacuum to get rid of any air(introduced through stirring/pouring) before adding the wood
->might make the epoxy itself a bit clearer and the vacuum pulling process a bit faster.
